Van Gogh ran after Gauguin with a knife after a heated argument in the flat 
they shared in Arles, Gauguin took out his sword that he carried in a 
sheath and sliced Van Gogh's ear off in self defense. Van Gogh went to the 
hospital and told them that he cut his own ear off to protect his dear 
friend. There seems to be evidence in letters that they wrote to each other 
that supports this theory.

top_comment.text:
The very first sentence of this video is incorrect.  The human brain is 
actually not good at recognizing patterns.  Yes, the brain does recognize 
many patterns, but it is not accurate at doing so.  It recognizes patterns 
which in fact are not actually patterns at all. Example the face on mars, 
numerous stereotypes, perhaps believing it more likely that a man suffering 
from mental illness recognized complex patterns of fluid dynamics and not 
that he just enjoyed painting swirly patterns and concentric circles, the 
belief that if all the cows are lying down in the pasture, fish will bite 
more than usual that day, throwing a virgin in the volcano will make it 
settle down and numerous more erroneous recognitions. ﻿
top_comment.author: wildbill6410

comments.text:
I just made a response above before I read yours. Most likely he was 
digoxin toxic...ge chewed on Foxglove leaves. Too much dig and you see 
halos around light sources!
comments.author: Kelly Krambeck

comments.text:
+Laurie Skelly I absolutely agree.  The narrator, makes an assumption. 
 Treats it as though it is a factually discovery.  Then marvels at how 
amazing the subject of his assumption is.  I think I would change my stance 
to acknowledging that the brain is indeed "good" at recognizing 
patterns...but tends to drop the ball when it comes to making accurate 
associations.  That problem would be due to a failure to exercise critical 
thinking, and not a physiological issue.
comments.author: wildbill6410

comments.text:
Also, "good" is subjective, but if we are "good" at flying commercial 
airliners without crashing them, then the brain is at least "very very very 
good" at recognizing patterns. Have you ever "named that tune"? Have you 
ever smiled, realizing you were listening to a creative cover of a familiar 
song? Have you ever deciphered a note written in bad handwriting? Have you 
ever held a conversation with someone with a thick accent? Have you ever 
verbed a noun?
comments.author: Laurie Skelly

comments.text:
Your point is fair, but I think it's a semantic distinction. The thing that 
the brain does very well is a kind of recognizing, and its successes are 
vast (like every time you see a face on the front of someone's head) and 
would go unnoticed if it weren't for those occasional false alarms and 
contextual slip-ups (like when you sometimes see a face in a bowl of fruit).
The brain does not describe patterns, though (he says "recognizing and 
describing"). I have no idea what that is supposed to mean. And other 
comments about the brain later in the video are much more starkly and 
bizarrely wrong.
comments.author: Laurie Skelly

top_comment.text:
The Turbulent Insights of a Turbulent Genius
How Van Gogh's art represents the science of turbulence

A wonderful example of how artists can depict the science of nature. In this case, Van Gogh's paintings from one of his most turbulent periods mirror the physical properties of the elusive physics concept of turbulence. And, of course, there's a bit of vision and neuroscience thrown in for good measure :)

h/t +Jonah Miller for sharing this wonderful, awe-inspiring, short video.

#ScienceSunday   #scisunABS

top_comment.text:
*The Turbulent Power of the Artist*

*Turbulence* is the tendency of fluids (and things that behave like fluids) 
to move chaotically and violently. Think the rapids in a fast-moving river. 
Making predictions about turbulent fluid flows is incredibly difficult... 
so difficult that we can't really do it.

But we can make heuristic arguments... In 1941, Russian physicist Andrey 
Kolmogorov (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov) made a very simple 
argument based on dimensional analysis that described the energy in a 
turbulent "wave" (in quotes because it's not really a wave) as a function 
of the "wavelength." This is the famous 5/3 law (
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turbulence#Kolmogorov.27s_theory_of_1941). 
Despite being a simple heuristic, the 5/3 law is amazingly accurate.

Amazingly, we recently discovered that many of Vincent Van Gogh's 
paintings, which look very turbulent by eye, actually *reflect* the 5/3 law 
extremely accurately.

Watch this *super cool* video to learn more.

(Thanks, +Lisa Guinther  for pointing me to this video!)

#physics     #ScienceSunday      #science   #fluids   #turbulence   #art  ﻿

*Physicist Werner Heisenberg said*, “When I meet God, I am going to ask him 
two questions: why relativity? And why turbulence? I really believe he will 
have an answer for the first.” As difficult as turbulence is to understand 
mathematically, we can use art to depict the way it looks. Natalya St. 
Clair illustrates how Van Gogh captured this deep mystery of movement, 
fluid and light in his work.
More: 
http://ed.ted.com/lessons/the-unexpected-math-behind-van-gogh-s-starry-night-natalya-st-clair

top_comment.text:
A "turbulent flow" was captured by Van Gogh 100 years before we discovered 
it.  Digitizing many of his paintings, it seems that the more psychotic he 
became the more "turbulence" he created.  Turbulence is real in the 
universe.  Did he know what he was doing?  No, he was neurotic and not too 
self-aware.  Besides no one knew.  Movement, fluid and light.  Look at his 
work and you'll see this fascinating factoid.﻿
top_comment.author: Catherine Rapicano

comments.text: Are they feeling alright #Rhedae? lol
comments.author: Catherine Rapicano

comments.text:
+alphabeticalor I'm sure this unheralded genius painted in his swirling, 
star-lit ways from something deep within him - surely what he saw is clear 
in so much of his works - wheat fields, night skies, daylight, he 
especially seemed taken with the fierceness of the high-noon sun.  It's 
staggering to think his vision wasn't taken seriously.
comments.author: Catherine Rapicano

comments.text:
thinking about it some more, what he was capturing there was what he saw of 
the Milky Way. in a world without electric streetlights, people used to be 
able to see the stars, and our galaxy is a distinct river of dim lights. 
you can still see it clearly if you get far enough away from all street 
lighting. people of his time could have seen it every night that wasn't 
cloudy. why he painted it as swirling is only his to know. again, this 
painting tells us nothing about fluid dynamics, and anyone with a drainpipe 
emptying into a rainbarrel, or a nearby creek and trees that drop leaves, 
or a spoon and a cookpot, could have told you hundreds if not thousands of 
years ago about how fluids swirl.
comments.author: alphabeticalor

comments.text:
+Rhedae Rogues 
Dear friend I have to say, I'm not a great fan of Modigliani, Picasso and 
especially Mondrian.  The angular, minimalist approach is not to my taste 
I'm afraid.  Give me a Rossetti anytime, a Vermeer, Degas, Rembrandt for 
his genius with light, and most of the old masters.  I'm most definitely an 
antique when it comes to paintings lol.  Art deco, modern art, it just 
leaves me nonplussed.  To each their own, yes?  As for Vincent, you're so 
right, his work is filled with 'la passionata' and depth, then you hear 
people say "My 5-year old could do better".  They just don't see it, but 
again, art is simply so individual and impossible to categorize.  We know 
what we like!  Warm hugs to everyone XOXO !!

Η περιδίνηση συμβαίνει για τον ίδιο λόγο που ανακατεύουμε ένα υγρό για να 
το αναμίξουμε με κάποιο άλλο. Ο ίδιος λόγος που ανακατεύουμε τα αισθήματά 
μας για να περιγράψουμε ό,τι δεν μπορούμε να αποκρυπτογραφήσουμε. Για τον 
ίδιο λόγο που οι ιμπρεσιονιστές εξέφραζαν αισθήματα και όχι στιγμές.

top_comment.text:
Physicist Werner Heisenberg said, “When I meet God, I am going to ask him 
two questions: why relativity? And why turbulence? I really believe he will 
have an answer for the first.” As difficult as turbulence is to understand 
mathematically, we can use art to depict the way it looks. Natalya St. 
Clair illustrates how Van Gogh captured this deep mystery of movement, 
fluid and light in his work.﻿
top_comment.author: TED-Ed

top_comment.text:
*The Turbulent Power of the Artist*

*Turbulence* is the tendency of fluids (and things that behave like fluids) 
to move chaotically and violently. Think the rapids in a fast-moving river. 
Making predictions about turbulent fluid flows is incredibly difficult... 
so difficult that we can't really do it.

But we can make heuristic arguments... In 1941, Russian physicist Andrey 
Kolmogorov (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov) made a very simple 
argument based on dimensional analysis that described the energy in a 
turbulent "wave" (in quotes because it's not really a wave) as a function 
of the "wavelength." This is the famous 5/3 law (
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turbulence#Kolmogorov.27s_theory_of_1941). 
Despite being a simple heuristic, the 5/3 law is amazingly accurate.

Amazingly, we recently discovered that many of Vincent Van Gogh's 
paintings, which look very turbulent by eye, actually *reflect* the 5/3 law 
extremely accurately.

Watch this *super cool* video to learn more.

(Thanks, +Lisa Guinther  for pointing me to this video!)

#physics     #ScienceSunday      #science   #fluids   #turbulence   #art  ﻿
top_comment.author: Tingiun Lin

captions.text:
One of the most remarkable aspects
of the human brain

is its ability to recognize patterns
and describe them.

Among the hardest patterns
we've tried to understand

is the concept of
turbulent flow in fluid dynamics.

The German physicist
Werner Heisenberg said,

"When I meet God,
I'm going to ask him two questions:
why relativity and why turbulence?

I really believe he will have
an answer for the first."

As difficult as turbulence is
to understand mathematically,
we can use art to depict the way it looks.

In June 1889, Vincent van Gogh
painted the view just before sunrise

from the window of his room
at the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum
in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence,

where he'd admitted himself after
mutilating his own ear
in a psychotic episode.

In "The Starry Night,"
his circular brushstrokes

create a night sky filled
with swirling clouds and eddies of stars.

Van Gogh and other Impressionists
represented light in a different way
than their predecessors,

seeming to capture
its motion, for instance,
across sun-dappled waters,

or here in star light
that twinkles and melts
through milky waves of blue night sky.
The effect is caused by luminance,

the intensity of the light
in the colors on the canvas.

The more primitive part
of our visual cortex,

which sees light contrast
and motion, but not color,

will blend two differently
colored areas together
if they have the same luminance.
But our brains' primate subdivision

will see the contrasting colors
without blending.

With these two interpretations
happening at once,

the light in many Impressionist works
seems to pulse, flicker and radiate oddly.

That's how this
and other Impressionist works

use quickly executed
prominent brushstrokes

to capture something strikingly real
about how light moves.

60 years later, Russian
mathematician Andrey Kolmogorov

furthered our mathematical
understanding of turbulence

when he proposed that energy
in a turbulent fluid at length R

varies in proportion to
the 5/3rds power of R.
Experimental measurements show Kolmogorov

was remarkably close
to the way turbulent flow works,

although a complete description
of turbulence

remains one of the unsolved
problems in physics.

A turbulent flow is self-similar
if there is an energy cascade.

In other words, big eddies
transfer their energy to smaller eddies,
which do likewise at other scales.

Examples of this include
Jupiter's Great Red Spot,

cloud formations
and interstellar dust particles.
In 2004, using the Hubble Space Telescope,

scientists saw the eddies of a distant
cloud of dust and gas around a star,

and it reminded them
of Van Gogh's "Starry Night."

This motivated scientists
from Mexico, Spain and England

to study the luminance
in Van Gogh's paintings in detail.

They discovered that there is a distinct
pattern of turbulent fluid structures

close to Kolmogorov's equation
hidden in many of Van Gogh's paintings.
The researchers digitized the paintings,

and measured how brightness varies
between any two pixels.

From the curves measured
for pixel separations,

they concluded that paintings from
Van Gogh's period of psychotic agitation

behave remarkably similar
to fluid turbulence.

His self-portrait with a pipe, from
a calmer period in Van Gogh's life,
showed no sign of this correspondence.
And neither did other artists' work

that seemed equally
turbulent at first glance,
like Munch's "The Scream."

While it's too easy to say
Van Gogh's turbulent genius
enabled him to depict turbulence,

it's also far too difficult to accurately
express the rousing beauty of the fact
that in a period of intense suffering,

Van Gogh was somehow
able to perceive and represent

one of the most supremely
difficult concepts
nature has ever brought before mankind,
and to unite his unique mind's eye

with the deepest mysteries
of movement, fluid and light.

title: The unexpected math behind Van Gogh's "Starry Night" - Natalya St. Clair
